results.title: Sister my sister
results.creator_credit: Nancy Meckler, Norma Heyman, Channel 4 and NFH Productions
results.brief_description: Based on a murder case which occurred in 1934 in a provincial French village, this psychological drama is set almost wholly within the claustrophobic confines of a bourgeois household. Two sisters are employed as maids for a prudish, arrogant, middle-aged widow and the frumpy grown daughter she clings to for companionship. Immaculately groomed and discreet, the sisters slave endlessly without complaint for years to meet the perfectionist standards of the mistress of the house. Seeking any relief from this cold, oppressive environment, the sisters, who are also bound to one another in an unhealthy co-dependent relationship, eventually become lovers. As their relationship becomes increasingly tortured, the burden of meeting their employer’s expectations strains class tensions to breaking point. Beginning with the scene of the horrific murder that almost inevitably occurs, the film then effectively builds the pressure cooker atmosphere of class division, sexual repression and co-dependence that provided fertile ground for this seemingly incomprehensible crime. Cast: Julie Waters, Joely Richardson, Jodhi May, Sophie Thursfield.

results.title: The Fox
results.creator_credit: Mark Rydell, Raymond Stross, Claridge Pictures and Motion Pictures International
results.brief_description: Based on D.H. Lawrence’s novella of the same name, “The Fox” is a study of human relationships and just how far the boundaries can be pushed in the name of love. Lesbian couple, Jill Banford (Sandy Dennis) and Ellen March, (Anne Heywood) fondly referred to as “March” by Jill, live in a remote snowbound cabin in the Canadian countryside where they struggle to live off a farm, raising a few chickens which to their dismay, are gradually being decimated by a marauding fox. To March, the fox has become symbolic, a challenge, at a time when she is beginning to question her relationship with Jill. Her moods have become reflective, her sexual desires repressed and unfulfilled. Jill, sensing the detachment, feels confused and insecure. With the unexpected arrival of Paul Grenfel (Keir Dullea), a young, goodlooking stranger, March and Jill’s world is turned completely upside down. The attraction between Paul and March brings conflict and tension for all three leading to an eventual confrontation where choices have to be made. The story is full of innuendos, symbolism and cliches but the acting is strong and the cinematography atmospheric. Screenplay by Lewis John Carlino and Howard Koch.

results.title: Flawless
results.creator_credit: Joel Schumacher, Jane Rosenthal and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Gruff, homophobic, retired security guard Walt Koontz (Robert De Niro) has, what he considers to be, the unlucky fortune of living opposite flamboyant drag queen Rusty Zimmerman (Philip Seymour Hoffman). However, after suffering a debilitating stroke in a fatality involving Rusty’s friend Amber, a tenuous link is formed between them. On advice from his physical therapist Walt asks Rusty for singing lessons to improve his speech - the constant taunting between them also helps the vocal chords. They slowly become involved in one another’s personal lives, if only playing out who faces the worst adversity and trotting off predictable homophobic and heterophobic comments. The subplot involving the retrieval of the stolen money that Amber lost her life for provides the film’s climax which is littered throughout with the usual tenets one expects from Joel Schumacher (slow-mo, image distortion), with a passing nod to “As good as it gets” in its intolerable male come good scenario, and a touch of humour. Cast also includes: Barry Miller, Daphne Rubin-Vega, Wanda de Jesus.

results.title: Rude
results.creator_credit: Clement Virgo, Colin Brunton, Damon D'Oliveira, Karen King, Conquering Lion Production and Feature Film Project
results.brief_description: This urban drama, the first feature length Canadian film to be made by an all black crew, is set amid a group of disenchanted black teenagers living in the ‘projects’ (public housing) who seek to express themselves, as they struggle against the confines of their lower class economic constraints that exclude them from mainstream society. Rude is an underground female pirate DJ who, seeking a voice for the troubles that seethe around her, transmits to the projects; General arrives home from jail spell for drug dealing to reconcile with his wife, Jessica (a police officer) and son; General’s brother longs for Jessica, and works for a white racist drug lord; Jordan, a young boxer, participates in gay bashing, despite his burgeoning desire for men; disconsolate Maxine reflects upon a failed relationship. The fortunes of these characters represent the disempowerment of Canadian minority groups, whose failure to have their cultural origins acknowledged within the broader milieu of the community is echoed in numerous misguided and frustrated acts of aggression. The explicit, rhythmic, political, and erotic rapping of Rude mirrors a potent narrative, moving and frightening in its intensity as it explores the themes of social isolation, homophobia, abortion, drug abuse and the violent expressions of youth.

results.title: Scenes from the class struggle in Beverly Hills
results.creator_credit: Paul Bartel, James C. Katz and North Street Films
results.brief_description: Director Paul Bartel (Eating Raoul, Lust in the Dust) brings a breezy, sophisticated touch to this outrageous sex farce set in Beverly Hills. The plot centres on the sexual antics that ensue when a snooty divorcee (Mary Woronov), her withdrawn teenage son, her pretentious playwright brother and his sassy black wife move in with their next door neighbour, a widowed ex-soap star (Jacqueline Bisset) while their house is being fumigated. Adding to the ‘upstairs-downstairs’ mix is the soap star’s precocious daughter, her campy friend and the women’s respective houseboys. When the two servants challenge each other to sleep with their respective employers, the stage is set for a wild weekend of bed swapping.

results.title: Topless women talk about their lives
results.creator_credit: Harry Sinclair, Fiona Copland, John Swimmer Productions and New Zealand Film Commission
results.brief_description: This fresh, low-budget, comedy of manners explores contemporary relationships through the romantic entanglements and dilemmas facing a circle of friends in their late twenties. Sinclair’s debut feature is based on a ‘micro series’ of 4 minute episodes he made for New Zealand television that followed events in the lives of a group of friends living in Auckland, and is similarly structured as a series of loosely connected episodes. Liz (Danielle Cormack) is disturbed to find that she is pregnant and potentially facing motherhood as a single mother. Her horny and geekish boyfriend (Joel Tobeck), is refusing to deal with the impending return of his other girlfriend from overseas. Prue (Willa O’Neill), Liz’s best friend, is having traumas of her own as she deals with the joys of her forthcoming marriage to Niue-born Mike (Shimpal Lelisi). Then there is the neurotic linchpin of the film, aspiring film-maker and “psychologically scarred” Ant (Ian Hughes) who experiences the trauma of attending the painfully bad premier screening of the feature film he has written. Featuring a music soundtrack by well known New Zealand acts including The Chills, The Clean, The Bats and Chris Knox, “Topless Women” effortlessly mixes comedy and drama to portray Gen-X angst.

results.title: Coming out under fire
results.creator_credit: Arthur E. Dong and Deepfocus Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the book of the same name by Allan Berube, who co-wrote the documentary, “Coming out under fire” interviews ten gays and lesbians who served in the military during the Second World War. Intercut with declassified military “education” films and newsreels, the interviews form a grave counterpoint to the campy, wholly ludicrious and sometimes painful stock footage where homosexuals were portrayed as darkly psychologically malevolent individuals. This entrenched homophobia resulted in anti-homosexual dragnets and entrapment schemes that caused great psychological distress to homosexuals within the military. The documentary is framed by the 1993 U.S. congressional hearings which resulted in the so-called “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy toward gays in the armed services, a policy which was calculated to please no-one and which was predicted to be a failure before it ever began, opening the gates once more on service-wide anti-homosexual entrapment schemes.

results.title: I like you: I like you very much
results.brief_description: This low-budget slice-of-life drama broke new ground in Japan in its representation of gay relationships and sex. The film centres on the shifting social and sexual relations between three teenage boys. The secure relationship between two of them, Shin and Yu, is jeopardised when Yu impulsively cruises a stranger waiting for a train and tells him that he likes him. This casual meeting sets off a series of sexual encounters. Shot in the port town of Kochi the film offers a candid portrayal of small-town gay lives and male desire. The first feature from high profile avant-garde filmmaker Oki, who directed, wrote, edited and photographed the film, it contains his trademark hand held camera work and informal visual style. The film falls into the Japanese genre of the “pink film” (or pinku eiga), a term that has been used since the 1960s to signify a variety of erotic, sado-erotic, and politico-erotic films, straight, gay, or in-between, whose small budgets, often brief running times, place them outside the genre of the mainstream feature. Cast includes Hisanori Kitakaze, Kazufumi Nishimoto and Hiroyuki Oki. In Japanese with English subtitles.

The film centres on the shifting social and sexual relations between three teenage boys. The secure relationship between two of them, Shin and Yu, is jeopardised when Yu impulsively cruises a stranger waiting for a train and tells him that he likes him. This casual meeting sets off a series of sexual encounters. Shot in the port town of Kochi the film offers a candid portrayal of small-town gay lives and male desire. The first feature from high profile avant-garde filmmaker Oki, who directed, wrote, edited and photographed the film, it contains his trademark hand held camera work and informal visual style. The film falls into the Japanese genre of the “pink film” (or pinku eiga), a term that has been used since the 1960s to signify a variety of erotic, sado-erotic, and politico-erotic films, straight, gay, or in-between, whose small budgets, often brief running times, place them outside the genre of the mainstream feature. Cast includes Hisanori Kitakaze, Kazufumi Nishimoto and Hiroyuki Oki. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Uncut
results.brief_description: This low budget experimental genre-bending exercise from Canadian director John Greyson revolves around the themes of censorship, circumcision and copyright. Greyson interweaves fiction and fact whilst commentating upon the vagaries of popular culture, with an examination of the history of censorship, raging against the conservatism of the era that does not recognise the importance of historical accuracy and truths. The fictional component of the film is set in Ottawa in 1979 and revolves around the fortunes of three Peters - one is writing a book against circumcision; the second is his typist who nurses an obsession with Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau; the third is a sinister presence who becomes intimately acquainted with the other two. The documentary component of the film (inter-cut with the fictional elements) concerns copyright laws and examines how such laws are homophobic and hamper creativity whilst protecting the rights and creative output of the rich and famous. Although this work is elliptical, it provides a fascinating cornucopia of issues from the perspective of a polemicist, presenting an irreverent and independent viewpoint about gay politics and mass culture. Cast includes Matthew Ferguson, Michael Achtman, Damon D’Oliveira.

results.title: Noir et blanc
results.creator_credit: Claire Devers, Les Films du Volcan and Ministère Français de la Culture
results.brief_description: A shy, world-weary accountant at a health club takes the advice of his employer to have a massage to relieve tension. The man, white and married, begins regular sessions with a taciturn black masseur, and a sadomasochistic relationship quickly develops between the two men. The accountant’s self-revelatory discovery of masochistic pleasure draws him ever more deeply into a world of pain and humiliation, inflicted in an atmosphere of sinister ritual and silent desire. Shot in black-and-white this understated and compelling film offers an oblique look at the cruel complexities of male relationships. Winner of the Camera d’Or at the 1986 Cannes film festival for best first feature, Devers’ film is based on the short story “Desire and the Black Masseur” by Tennessee Williams. Cast includes Francis Frappat, Jacques Martial, Josephine Fresson and Marc Berman. Written by Claire Devers. Photography by Daniel Desbois, Christopher Doyle, Alain Lasfargues and Jean-Paul de Costa. In French with English subtitles.
